column2: ENGLISH.
The University of Oxford
Teaching at Oxford existed in some form as early as 1096. The history and influence of the University of Oxford has made it one of the most prestigious universities in the world.
Sacred Monastery of Mount Sinai
The Sacred Monastery of the God-Trodden Mount Sinai lies near the town of St. Catherine. Built around 550, it is one of the oldest working Christian monasteries in the world.
High Cathedral of Saint Peter

Trier Cathedral is the oldest church in Germany and the largest religious structure in Trier, notable for its grand design. The central part of the nave was built of Roman brick in the early fourth century.
Church of Our Lady Mary of Zion
Founded during the episcopacy of Bishop Frumentius, the Church of Our Lady Mary of Zion has been destroyed and rebuilt at least twice. It is claimed to contain the Ark of the Covenant.
Katedrala Svetog Duje
The Cathedral of St. Domnius is a complex of a church, formed from an Imperial Roman mausoleum, with a bell tower. The church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and the bell tower to Saint Domnius.
Aachener Dom
Aachen Cathedral is a Catholic church in west Germany. Construction was ordered by Charlemagne and it is claimed as one of the oldest cathedrals in Europe.
Pisa Cathedral
Pisa Cathedral is a Roman Catholic cathedral dedicated to the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, in the Piazza dei Miracoli. It is the seat of the Archbishop of Pisa.
Catedral de Santiago de Compostela
The Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela is the reputed burial place of Saint James the Great. The cathedral has historically been a place of pilgrimage on the Way of St. James.
Monuments at Mahabalipuram
A collection of  religious monuments in the coastal town of Mahabalipuram. The site has 400 ancient monuments and tamil religious temples. Most were built during the Pallava dynasty.
Anantashayana Vishnu
Anantashayi Vishnu is a large open air rock relief of the Hindu god Vishnu, carved during the early 9th Century in the Saranga village. It is located on the left bank of the Brahmani River.
Mausoleo di Teodorico
The Mausoleum of Theoderic is an ancient monument just outside Ravenna. It was built in 520 AD by Theoderic the Great as his future tomb. The roof is a single 230 tonne Istrian stone.
Aramgahe Kourosh-e Bozorg
Cyrus the Great, founder of the Persian Empire, ordered the construction of this monumental tomb southwest of the palaces of Pasargadae. According to Greek sources, it dates back to around 550 BC.
Madghacen
Madghacen is a royal mausoleum-temple of the ancient Berber Kings which stands near Batna city in Numidia.
Arg-e Rayen
Rayen Castle is an adobe citadel on the skirts of the mountain Hezar, known for trading valuable goods and quality textiles. It is also a centre of sword and knife manufacturing.
Sankoré Madrasah
The University of Sankoré is an eminent and ancient center of learning. It has its roots in the mosque which was founded in 989AD by Al-Qadi Aqib ibn Mahmud.
Locmariaquer Menhirs
The Locmariaquer Menhirs are a complex of constructions in Brittany. 'The Broken Menhir of Er Grah' is the largest block of stone to have been transported by ancient people.
Taq-e Bostan
The Arch of the Garden is a site with a series of large Persian Sassanid rock reliefs, carved around the 4th century AD. It is located in the heart of the Zagros mountains.
Heidentor Carnuntum
The Heidentor, also known as Pagans' Gate, is the ruin of a triumphal arch of the Roman Empire, located in what was the fort-city of Carnuntum. Erected during the reign of Emperor Constantius II.
Colonne di San Lorenzo
The Columns of San Lorenzo are a group of ancient Roman ruins, located in front of the Basilica of San Lorenzo in the city of Milan. The colonnade consists of 16 tall Corinthian columns in a row.
Colossus of Barletta
The Colossus is a large bronze statue of an unknown Eastern Roman Emperor, nearly three times life size. The statue washed up on shore after the sinking of a Venetian merchant vessel.
Columns originally constructed as part of a pagan temple.
Columns moved to their current location.
Construction ordered by Theoderic the Great
